results.title: Vivien Leigh: Scarlett and Beyond
results.creator_credit: Turner Pictures, Wombat Productions, Inc., Gene Feldman and Suzette Winter
results.brief_description: Jessica Lange hosts this tribute to Vivien Leigh which looks at her life both on-stage and off-stage. Uses clips from films such as “Gone with the wind”, “A Streetcar named Desire” and “The Roman spring of Mrs. Stone” to illustrate her impressive career as an actress and includes interviews with friends and fellow actors which provide an insight into her private life including her marriage to Laurence Olivier and her struggle with physical and mental illness.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Turner Pictures, Wombat Productions, Inc., Gene Feldman and Suzette Winter

results.title: Vivian Bullwinkel
results.creator_credit: Ron Hardy, Pamela Vanneck and Ron Saunders
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Willesee’s Australians”.
Vivian Bullwinkle was a volunteer nurse during the Second World War. While being evacuated from Singapore the ship on which she was travelling sank. The small group of survivors washed ashore surrendered to the Japanese occupying Banka Island. In a horrific turn of events Japanese troops bayoneted the surviving soldiers and ordered the nurses back into the water. Bullwinkle was shot but miraculously survived. Bleeding and in a state she drifted ashore and hid in the jungle. Discovering a badly wounded British soldier she realised the only chance of survival was to again surrender to the Japanese soldiers.

results.title: Vivement Dimanche! = Confidentially Yours!
results.brief_description:
Julien Vercel is a real-estate dealer accused of killing his wife and her lover. He hides in his office while his secretary Barbara sets out to discover what really happened and why. When Barbara starts looking into the dark past of her boss’s wife, she comes across illicit love affairs, a prostitution ring and shady private detectives. “I liked the idea of a ‘serie noire’ (detective novel) without gangsters. Second, the relationship between a secretary and her boss, which can be so amusing, has not been explored in recent films. And most of all, I wanted to make a detective film with Fanny Ardant. I read many novels by Williams and found that he created the best roles for women. I liked the idea of an ‘ordinary’ woman from daily life conducting the investigation. Fanny represents in France a certain elegance and lyricism. I wanted to show that she could be a comedienne - in a popular role, behind a typewriter.” Reference: Annette Insdorf. ‘Francois Truffaut’. Cambridge University Press, 1994.

Credits: Producer, Armand Barbault ; director, Francois Truffaut ; writers, Francois Truffaut, Suzanne Schiffman, Jean Aurel ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; music, Georges Delerue ; art direction, Hilton McConnico.
Cast: Fanny Ardant, Jean-Louis Trintignant, Philippe Laudenbach, Caroline Sihol, Philippe Morier-Genoud, Jean-Pierre Kalfon.

results.title: Vive le tour = Twist encore
results.brief_description: Following the success of his early films, Louis Malle offered himself a small treat: a short film of the 1962 Tour de France. Malle has always been fond of cycling, and the ‘little queen’ features prominently in most of his films. For Malle, making ‘Vive le Tour’ was an opportunity to renew a fascination dating back from childhood, when he would follow the great race on the radio. By the time this documentary was made, the ‘Tour’ had become a huge sporting and social phenomenon, due partly to television coverage. ‘Vive le tour’ attaches itself not just to the athletes, but also to the press entourage and the crowd, while brushing upon the already sensitive subject of drug use. “When I shot ‘Vive le Tour’, what struck me was the violence, the suffering - it’s probably the toughest sport that exists. So I filmed that: the accidents, the falls, the incredible effort when they climb mountain and how it’s seen on their faces.” Reference: Philip French (1993) Malle on Malle, Faber and Faber. Narration in English by Louis Malle.

results.title: Vivaldi: the Four Seasons
results.creator_credit: Elkins Organization, Le'an Films, Harry Waterson, Eitan Even and Allan Miller
results.brief_description: A stunnning performance of Vivaldi’s Four Seasons by violinists Isaac Stern (Spring), Pinchas Zukerman (Summer), Shlomo Mintz (Autumn), Itzhak Perlman (Winter) supported by the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra and conducted by Zubin Mehta as part of the Huberman Festival staged at the Frederick R. Mann Auditorium, Tel Aviv in 1983. This truly beautiful music is interspersed with acompanying images of Israel and Palestine depicting the mood of each of the seasons.

results.title: Vivaldi's Venice
results.brief_description: Six 18th century concerti of Vivaldi sustain the sensuous poetry of the camera as it reflects Venice’s glories and variety of moods through Vivaldi’s, The 4 Seasons - Winter-Autumn Concerto. (Award: “Osella D’Argento” 30th International Exhibition of Cinematographic Art, Venice, August 1969)

results.title: Viva Zapata! [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Darryl F. Zanuck, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Elia Kazan
results.brief_description: This dramatisation of the role of the peasant leader Emilio Zapata in the Mexican Revolution was the product of a close collaboration between screenwriter John Steinbeck and director Elia Kazan. Zapata (played by Marlon Brando), an ambiguous historical figure, is idealised in the film yet a certain psychological complexity is maintained. He is a symbolic figure, a ‘natural’ leader who is attuned to the essential needs of the people. Revolution thus becomes a natural rather than a revolutionary process. The weak idealist, Madero, cannot make the revolution work. The shadowy figure of Fernando, the advisor, stands as a symbol for Stalinism. Cast also includes Jean Peters, Anthony Quinn, Joseph Wiseman and Arnold Moss.

results.title: Viva Las Vegas = Love in Las Vegas
results.creator_credit: Jack Cummings, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and George Sidney
results.brief_description: Elvis Presley stars as racing car driver Lucky Jackson, a man determined to win the Las Vegas Grand Prix and triumph over his number one competitor, Count Elmo Mancini (Cesare Danova). The Count is like Lucky in many respects, a determined, thrillseeking ladies man, which makes defeating him even more difficult. To finance his vehicular obsession (and to purchase the most important item - the engine), he performs as a singing waiter, thus giving Elvis the chance to demonstrate his crooning and hip swinging capabilities. The task proves harder than first thought due to the distraction of sexy swimming instructor Rusty Martin (Ann-Margaret), as Lucky faces the prospect of losing love as well as the race. Elvis’ fourteenth movie includes hits such as “The Lady loves me”, “What’d I say”, “C’mon everybody” and “Viva Las Vegas”. Cast also includes Cesare Danova, William Demarest and Nicky Blair. Contains the original theatrical trailer.

results.title: Viva Falantil!
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, SKA TV and Campbell Manderson
results.brief_description: Report on a group of performers and activists who stowed away on a UN flight bound for East Timor to raise awareness of the plight of the Falintil people and their 20 year struggle against the East Timorese military. A tour through a newly-independent East Timor, still shell-shocked and facing an uncertain future. This story examines the possibilities for and obstacles to building a democratic nation. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
